column8: which is allowed under NFL rules after players have three year of tenure. Joe would not wager on that being a random comment from Barton. column1: https://www.joebucsfan.com/2025/02/two-major-areas-where-graham-barton-must-improve/|Two Major Areas Where Graham Barton Must Improve|After 1
column3: Bucs center Graham Barton has a microscope on his performance — and that’s not just about what happens after the snap. Speaking on SiriusXM NFL Radio this week
column4: Barton noted the two areas in which he must improve significantly. He says he has to be more steady in his play and do a better job of mastering defenses. “Just being out there and being able to communicate with confidence and be able to
column6: play a consistent four quarters. Those are the two big areas that I want to continue to improve on
column7: ” Barton said. “Just learning a new position
column8: not coming up to the line of scrimmage and getting a defensive front that might be unfamiliar … I want to be able to confidently know what I’m seeing
column10: and be able to get everyone on the same page in a timely manner. “I think that’s the most important job for a center. [It’s] something I look forward to improving on. And that just comes through
column14: understanding the defensive coordinator you’re playing against and their tendencies … and where on the field and what situations they like to do it in. I think that’s honestly the most important thing.” Barton added that consistency and understanding defenses were his two greatest NFL challenges after the Bucs made him their first-round pick in the 2024 NFL Draft. He went on to talk about how NFL defensive coordinators “throw you off
column15: ” especially rookies. Barton had an excellent rookie year and has all the mental and physical tools to make a significant sophomore leap next season. Still
column17: Joe expects Barton to get stronger and play faster

column1: https://www.joebucsfan.com/2025/02/josh-grizzard-and-the-bucs-defense/|Josh Grizzard And The Bucs Defense|Rookie Bucs offensive coordinator Josh Grizzard wants something that might not soothe Bucs fans. Grizzard wants shorter drives after the Bucs ranked third in the NFL last season in time of possession at 31:41 per game. The Super Bowl champion Eagles ranked No. 1 and the explosive Lions were No. 2. Scoring faster sounds great
column2: and theoretically it cuts the chances for drive-killing mistakes
column3: but it’s not ideal when your defense is soft like the Bucs’ was in 2024. “We do want push the ball down the field a little bit more. That can create a little bit shorter drives
column4: ” Grizzard told The JoeBucsFan Show on WDAE radio on Saturday. “You’re not necessarily going through 12-play drives
column5: 11-play drives all the time. And that’s going to be dependent upon the personnel
column6: so it’s something to look forward to doing this spring and getting rolling for the season.” Indeed it will depend a lot on personnel. The Bucs should be more explosive if a healthy Chris Godwin returns and takes pressure off second-year receiver Jalen McMillan. And Joe would love to see growth from tight ends Devin Culp and Payne Durham
column7: who have flashed a lot of potential behind Cade Otton. Speedy Trey Palmer had 39 catches as a rookie and nearly was invisible last season
column8: so there’s potential there. Palmer is 23 years old. Joe also is intrigued to see how much of Mike McDaniel’s Dolphins offense shows up in Tampa. Grizzard told The Drive on WDAE that without two years under McDaniel he wouldn’t have been qualified to interview to work for the Bucs a year ago. Grizzard stressed that years with McDaniel taught him “manipulation of defenses through motion and the utilization of tape.” If Grizzard does shorten drives
column9: that would represent another reason to pray the Bucs defense tightens up.|2025-02-20 10:20:00|303|21|4|Josh Grizzard|Grizzard aims to shorten Bucs' drives for stronger defense.|7|Mixed sentiments with focus on offense

column1: https://www.joebucsfan.com/2025/02/chris-godwins-hidden-value/|Chris Godwin’s Hidden Value|One thing other than defenders not wrapping up ballcarriers that drives Joe up a tree is when on third (or fourth) downs
column2: quarterbacks go turtle. What does this mean? It’s when quarterbacks
column4: throw short of the sticks. Joe goes absolutely mental over this. It was a hallmark of the Mike Glennon era of Bucs football. Apparently
column5: Baker Mayfield did this more than Joe thought. But this isn’t to bash Mayfield. Instead
column6: it’s to praise the guy Mayfield threw to when he did throw short of the sticks. Until Chris Godwin got hurt
column7: he led the league in taking passes short of the sticks and turning them into first downs. That’s what good guy Kevin Clark of ESPN said this week when he appeared on Mina Kimes’ podcast. Clark didn’t have the figures
column8: but he used this intel to buoy his take that if Godwin hits the free agent market on March 12
column9: his agent will become a very popular man and Godwin may be an even richer young man. “Godwin led the league in quick throws
column11: stating he read the stats on Mayfield and Godwin just before he chatted with Kimes. “He led the league in [short] passes until he got hurt. He had the ankle injury
column13: we’re [expecting Godwin] to be fully healthy
column15: all that stuff. But until he got hurt
column16: he was basically leading the league in passes
column17: short of the sticks that [were converted to first downs] after the catch.” Clark added when you combine Godwin’s production with how much of a class act he is — and a hard worker and a team-first guy — a team would be nuts not to reach out to his agent. Clark also suggested it would be very wise for Bucs AC/DC-loving general manager Jason Licht to lock up Godwin before he has a chance to dip a toe in the free agent waters. Because if he does
column19: Godwin will get all sorts of cash thrown in his face. “I think when you hear that [about Godwin converting short passes to first downs]
column21: every single quarterback can benefit from that kind of guy
column22: ” Clark said. To listen to Clark talk
column23: he thinks the only other wide receiver who would draw more interest is Cincinnati’s Tee Higgins. Clark seems spot on. And that’s very likely why Licht and Godwin’s camp agreed Tuesday on a two-week extension to hammer out a contract.|2025-02-20 07:00:00|416|27|7|Chris Godwin|Godwin excels at converting short passes into first downs effectively.|4|Mixed sentiments towards Chris Godwin's future with the Bucs

column1: https://www.joebucsfan.com/2025/02/adam-rank-chris-godwin-should-leave-bucs/|Adam Rank: Chris Godwin Should Leave Bucs|So Tuesday word broke that Chris Godwin’s camp agreed with Bucs AC/DC-loving general manager Jason Licht to extend a deadline that would have forced a dead money hit on the Bucs’ salary cap. This extension
column2: right up to the free agency dinner bell on March 12
column3: gave the Bucs two extra weeks to try hammer out a deal. In Joe’s mind
column4: that doesn’t happen unless the two sides were deep in talks or a contract was within reach. Otherwise
column5: why else would a player’s agent agree to a contract negotiation extension? One reason the Bucs may be motivated to get Godwin done soon is that he ought to be a very popular target on the open market. NFL Network/NFL.com humorist (?) Adam Rank thinks Godwin needs to hit the open market. Rank doesn’t believe the Bucs need to bend over backward if Godwin hits free agency. Godwin will have a lot of cash thrown at him and the Bucs
column9: Godwin should pack up and leave Tampa for greener grasses (and a greener check).  Godwin had an abrupt and devastating end to his 2024 campaign — dislocating his ankle in Week 7 — but he still figures to garner plenty of interest on the open market. And following his injury
column10: Tampa Bay was forced to turn the page
column11: with rookie Jalen McMillan really coming on late last season. One team that could be a really nice fit for the well-rounded Godwin: the Rams. Joe is a big fan of Jalen McMillan. How could a Bucs fan not be? But with rookies
column12: it’s always interesting to see how they adjust or if they can adjust. After an offensive player’s rookie season
column13: defensive coordinators have all offseason to hatch ways to stop a player who in the final weeks of the previous season balled out. Joe is very hopeful McMillan will continue to grow. But that’s not yet a done deal. Godwin brings excellence to the table. So Joe isn’t ready to allow Godwin to walk out the door if the Bucs and Godwin’s camp are within striking distance of a new contract. Besides
